trial_identification.studytitle: Effect of fat consumption on postprandial blood glycemic, insulinemic and incretin responses in healthy volunteers.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Effect of fat consumption on postprandial blood glycemic, insulinemic and incretin responses in healthy volunteers

conditions.healthcondition: Prevention and management of both type 1 and type 2 diabetes.

interventions.interventions: Using standard Glycemic Index (GI) testing methodology, 10 volunteers, over 6 randomised occasions, (1 week between visits) will ingest 3 glucose reference drinks (50 g glucose) and 3 flat-bread meals differing in fat content (5, 15 and 30% - 3.44, 10.33 and 20.66 g respectively) after an overnight fast. The flat-bread meals are labelled with 13C octanoic acid (1microlitre/g food). Baseline and postprandial measures of blood glucose, insulin and satiety hormones, as well as measures of gastric-emptying rate via breath-test will be taken.
interventions.comparator: Postprandial responses to the flat-bread meals are expressed as a percentage of the responses to the glucose reference drinks.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Attenuation of glycemic response with increased fat dose.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Fasting then blood samples at 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, 120 and 180mins postprandial

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Increased satiety hormone responses with increased fat dose.
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Fasting then 15, 30, 45, 60, 90, 120 and 180 mins samples postprandial.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Healthy volunteers between the ages of 18 and 60.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Presence of diabetes, or other metabolic diseases known to impact on glycemic control.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Gate 13 Kintore Avenue, Adelaide, South Australia 5000

fundingsource.fundingname: Food Futures, Australian Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation (CSIRO) Human Nutrition, New Zealand Institute for Plant and Food Research Ltd.
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Gate 13 Kintore Avenue, Adelaide, South Australia 5000

secondarysponsor.sponsorname: New Zealand Institute for Plant and Food Research Ltd.
secondarysponsor.sponsoraddress: New Zealand Institute for Plant and Food Research Ltd. Private Bag 11 600, Palmerston North, New Zealand

ethicsAndSummary.summary: To better understand the role played by fat as a food ingredient in decreasing the rate at which a given foods' carbohydrate component is digested and absorbed into the blood stream in the form of glucose.
